One question I am doing myself is a pretty basic one: did anyone check what is the average time for this type of acquisition deals to be agreed? As usual the first thing to do is to look at base rates, which I did not do myself. A second constraint is of course the Chinese government: the first update of the list of no-export technologies in 12 years just happened when the Tiktok deal seemed to be approaching. This indicates a certain probability that the Chinese gov simply want to avoid the sale of Tiktop. If I use "phase space approximation" (i.e. a physicists term to indicate that I equally distribute the probability between all the possibilities, in this case "yes" or "no"), this gives me a 50% chance that the deal will never be approved. This in turn could be compatible with the discussion that is going on in the Chinese internet, in which there seems to be a tendency towards "不能卖" (cannot be sold). Another reason to increase the probability of a "no", at least a temporary one, is that the Chinese gov is likely to be waiting to what happens in the US elections. They might have the hope that if Biden wins, the situation could change: Tiktok could be used again in the US, still in the hands of Bytedance, and all these sweet user data of American users at the disposition of the CCP at the moment they want. So why rush if there is this possibility? But even if we are in the timeline in which the Chinese gov will allow Titkok to be sold, the approval requires at least 30 days, probably more. The wording of the question is whether a deal would be announced, and the deal could indeed be announced before the approval of the Chinese gov (and later maybe recanted if things go south?), but this does not look the most sensible thing to do.

Like My colleagues, we can simplify this problem into event spaces.
The first is Event(A) = Microsoft does not announce deal before November 1. I view this option as the same as if Microsoft not announcing a deal at all. In a recent news, China has implemented new export restrictions that potentially can block or delay any deal for ByteDance to sell operations to the US.  Further, the US elections is on November 2nd, and if President Trump does not win, the pressure for ByteDance to sell TikTok may dissipate. I also believe that if ByteDance sells TikTok before November 1st, it will come across as if sold only because Trump forced them too, a weak image for Chinese tech stocks that China would likely not want to display.  Next is Event(B), Microsoft does announce deal. In this event space, either MSFT announces before September 16th or between September 16th and October 31st.  We know from statements made on Aug 2nd by MSFT, they stated that they will make a decision by September 15th in any event. Further, it is now known that Microsoft has teamed up with Walmart and Oracle indicating that they are still strongly considering a TikTok purchase.  It is difficult to empirically quantify the probability in each event space, so heuristically I will assign the following; I believe it is unlikely a deal will be announced by MSFT before November 1st, so I assign this a 65% probability. In the remaining 35%, I believe strongly that is MSFT were to make a deal for TikTok, it would happen at their originally stated deadline, Sept 15th. Let’s call the probability that MSFT announces a deal before Sept 15th, P(X|B), where B is the event space B defined above, and I assign this a probability of 75%. Likewise, let P(Y|B) be event space Y where Y represents MSFT announcing the deal between Sept 16th and Oct 31st. P(Y|B) will be assigned a probability of 0.25%. I give some probability to this event happening because it is possible that the original statements made my MSFT were contingent on the White House’s  initial deadline of Sept 20th, which has now been pushed back. From the above we see that:
P(Not Before Nov 1st) = 0.65
P(Between Sept 16th and Nov 1st) = P(Y|B)*P(B) = 0.25*0.35 = 0.0875
P(Before Sept 16th) = P(X|B) *P(B) = 0.75*0.35 = 0.27
I round up the middle bucket to make up my weights.

Two components, timing and acquirer:  Trump has set a 9/20th deadline at first. Though he has also set an extended deadline through November, it's possible that he will insist on the original deadline holding, and at a recent press conference he said that this deadline holds. The counterpoint is that Beijing has included TikTok in their banned export technologies, which would take 30 days for Beijing to approve the transaction.  Additionally, it is possible that Oracle or other names can also bid for TikTok. Thus, much of the mass that Microsoft does not win the bid should be included in the "Not before 11/1" category.

The first goal is to determine the probability that Microsoft will be the one to announce the deal given a deal is announced. The two main players seem to be Microsoft and Oracle, although it seems other players may be interested. Regardless, Microsoft seems to be the frontrunner, so I’ll give it a 75% chance of getting the acquisition at all. There have been frequent delays due to regulation, but it seems Trump has given the company a deadline of November 12. Thus, I believe if the deal were to happen, it would need to happen before then. It is difficult to estimate the probability of the deal being announced, but at this point it seems like there is over a 90% chance given the number of interesting players having discussions.

Even though usually we would model scenarios starting with an outside view, TikTok is not a usual acquisition case, but is rather a unique one off event created by macro factors. Therefore, to come up with a distribution for the announcement date, we used a more situation dependent approach. Official deadlines:
Microsoft deadline: As pointed out by @pchi, Microsoft made it clear in an announcement on August 2 that they will make a decision "in any event event no later than September 15".
US administration deadline: The current US administration will restrict US companies transacting with ByteDance by September 20, with a deal completion extended to happen by November 12. Other participants:
Competitors: The question asks about Microsoft announcing the deal, however, there are only other companies interested in the acquisition. Main contenders include Oracle, Twitter, Walmart, Facebook. These companies also have cash flow and balance sheet positions that would allow the (current) $20B purchase price. Furthermore, Oracle is also considering sweetening the deal for current ByteDance owners by offering participations in company profits for the next 2 years.
Chinese government: Two days ago the Chinese government also raised its voice and pointed out that the IP is Chinese, thus they will also need to approve the transaction. This just complicates the US-China relations further and may be the main reason none of the contenders have announced a deal yet. Therefore, in conclusion market seems to imply a 35% chance that Microsoft will not be the company to announce the deal. We furthermore weight that for the rest there is a 10% chance (in total 6%) of the deadlines being pushed further out and/or deal falling apart. However, the deadlines are unlikely to go out more than October 31, given that US elections are on November 3 and China is one of the current administration's target for convincing voters. The September 15 deadline by Microsoft was set a month ago and a lot has changed ever since. Therefore, it is not improbable that they will be also more lenient on their internally set deadline.

I broke down this question into two sub-questions: 1) Will Microsoft be the one who acquired Tik Tok, and 2) if 1) is true, when the announcement will be. Up until 9/3/2020, Trump has announced that Tik Tok now has an extra 45 days to complete the acquisition on or before 11/15/2020, China has put additional protective measures on Tik Tok's core algorithm, and Oracle/Softbank are joining the bidding war.  Considering this kind of forced acquisition is fairly unprecedented, I decide to bring more inside view than outside view when analyzing this question. Even though Microsoft is a strong buyer, Softbank has a lot of capital to potentially outbid Microsft, and Oracle is willing to buy Tik Tok for half of its cash flow, I will assign 50% probability to Microsoft winning the bill. On the other hand, I assign the probability of China willing to let Tik Tok go/Tik Tok willing to sell to be 40% because both of them have shown evidence to fight back on the forced sale (China's announcement on its potential regulations on Tik Tok's core algo and Tik Tok's law suit against Trump administration). It is to Tik Tok and China's benefit to drag the acquisition longer.  Thus, the first scenario happens when the acquirer is Microsoft + China gives Microsoft a go before September 16. Because of the recent escalation discussed before, I will adjust the latter probability from the 0.4 baseline to 0.3. The total probability is 0.5 * 0.3 =   0.15.

The second scenario happens when the acquirer is Microsoft + China gives Microsoft a go between September 16 and October 31.  The total probability is 0.5 * 0.5 =   0.25. My last scenario is deal not happening at all/the deal drags along/the acquirer is not Microsoft, which has a 60% probability.

Because this is such an unpredictable question, I had to make some assumptions. The first was that Microsoft/Walmart and Oracle, the two most likely groups to acquire Tik Tok, are interchangeable. I assumed that since the first group has two major players, it has a 2/3 chance to receive the deal, conditional on a deal occurring. I decided to break up the problem into two events, which I treated as independent. Event A: The group attempting to acquire TikTok would be willing to accept a deal without TikTok's proprietary algorithm. I gave this the most naive probability possible, P(A)=0.5 Event B: Beijing will ultimately be willing to approve of an acquisition deal which includes the algorithm. Despite the recent tariff expansion, I wanted to leave out any kind of bias and also give this event P(B)=0.5 Let D be the event that a deal is made before the November 14 deadline that the acquisition has been given. By the law of total probability and the independence of A and B we have
P(D) = P(D|A,B)P(B) + P(D|A, not B)P(not B) + P(Deal|not A, B)P(B) + P(Deal|not A, not B)P(not B)
If A and B occur, then there is a higher chance of the deal occurring. Beijing would be willing to give up the algorithm and the buyer would be willing to make a deal without it, so there's more flexibility on both sides. However the deal could take until the November 14 deadline, and a deal this size always has the chance to fall through, so I set P(D|A,B)=0.75. If A occurs but B does not then a deal will come through if there aren't any more legal obstacles from Beijing's side blocking a deal without the algorithm. Combined with other things that could go wrong, I give P(D|A, not B)=0.50. If B occurs but not A, then by similar logic, I give P(D|B, not A)=0.50. One side is less flexible and things could go wrong in a variety of ways preventing a deal by November 14. Finally, if neither A nor B occurs, then a deal is unlikely. Beijing will not allow the sale of the algorithm, and the US counterpart will not accept a deal without it. So I assign P(D|not A, not B)=0. Altogether this gives us
P(D) = 0.75*0.5 + 0.5*0.5 + 0.5*0.5 + 0*0.5 = 0.875
and since Microsoft/Walmart has a 2/3 probability of being the US entity to acquire TikTok, this puts the probability of Microsoft/Walmart announcing TikTok before November 14 at 0.5775. Therefore we have an upper bound on the probability of an announcement at 0.5775. The crux of the problem is how much of this probability to assign to each period. If we did this in proportion with the length of each period we would end up with Before 16 September: (12/72) * 0.5775 = .09625
Between 16 September and 31 October: (45/72) * 0.5775 = .3609375
Between 31 October and 14 November: (15/72) * 0.5775 = .1203125 Frankly I do not think I have enough knowledge about these kinds of acquisitions to use any metric which is not linear with time. Thus I ended up with the first two probabilities above, along with them subtracted from 1 (which encompasses the third probability).

September 16th is only a few days before Trump's ban of the app takes effect, meaning if a deal is going to be struck between Microsoft and ByteDance, it will almost definitely be announced before then. Microsoft has recently announced their interest in acquiring the app and, after initially threatening to ban the app altogether, Trump has announced his official support for the acquisition. This is important for two reasons. (1) It shows Microsoft is serious about buying it and believes it is in a strong enough position to openly admit that (no backdoor deals or playing it close to the chest). (2) It suggests that the President intends to ban the app if the deal were not to go through, meaning ByteDance would lose a huge amount of money if they don't sell. As such, Microsoft will likely get a deal on the sale and ByteDance would be able to avoid huge losses, a rare win-win for such a large acquisition. Once the app is banned within the US, however, Microsoft's incentive to buy becomes almost zero (and potentially negative given legal and administrative expenses) and ByteDance will have already absorbed the loss. Therefore, the situational economics suggest that the deal should at least be announced sooner rather than later.
